video.title_en: ROGER BACON - Advocate of Experimental Science

summary.text_en: Roger Bacon, known as 'Doctor Mirabilis', completed his magnum opus 'Opus Majus' in 1267 and secretly sent it to Pope Clement IV. In it, he passionately advocated for 'Experimental Science' (Scientia Experimentalis) over blind reliance on authority. In the section on optics, heavily influenced by the Arab scholar Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen), he detailed the anatomy of the eye, reflection, and refraction, and correctly proposed that convex lenses could be used to correct vision (the principle of eyeglasses).
key_points_en: Introduced Ibn al-Haytham's (`ibn_al_haytham_optics_1021`) optics to Europe
Described the principle of lenses correcting vision (eyeglasses)
Predicted telescopes, microscopes, and powered machines

story.text_en: Bacon was a Franciscan friar, but his order banned publishing books without approval. Luckily, Pope Clement IV was a secret admirer and ordered Bacon to write down his knowledge in secret. Working in secrecy and poverty, Bacon produced the 'Opus Majus'. In it, he not only explained the rainbow (reflection and refraction) but made stunning technological predictions: 'Instruments may be made so that things far away appear close (telescopes)... carriages without animals to move them (cars), and machines for flying like a bird.' The book was a beacon of scientific thought in the Middle Ages.

fun_facts.text_en: Bacon wrote that lenses would be useful for 'old men and those with weak sight'. Within decades of his writing (c. 1280s), eyeglasses were invented in Italy, likely influenced by his theories.
He was one of the first Europeans to record the formula for 'gunpowder'. To keep it secret, he wrote the recipe as a Latin 'anagram'.

simple_explanation.text_en: In the Middle Ages, if you had a question, you checked 'what Aristotle said'. Bacon said, 'Don't just listen to the ancients, do an experiment!' He was obsessed with light. He read the Arab scientist Ibn al-Haytham and told Europe: 'Light can be bent.' He proposed that if you shape glass into a curve (convex lens), it makes small letters look big. Although he didn't build a telescope, he basically wrote the 'instruction manual' saying it was possible.

applications.text_en: He was one of the first in Europe to advocate for 'induction' and 'experimental verification', laying the groundwork for the later Galileo and Francis Bacon.

impact.text_en: Roger Bacon was the crucial bridge between 'Islamic Golden Age Science' (especially Al-Haytham) and the 'European Renaissance'. He introduced rigorous optical geometry to Europe and planted the seed that 'experiment beats authority'. Though imprisoned and banned during his life, his ideas (especially on lenses and experiment) bore fruit centuries later.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Ibn al-Haytham (Bacon quotes 'Alhacen' frequently; his optical theory is almost entirely based on Haytham's work)
Aristotle (While Bacon criticized blind adherence, he was deeply trained in the Aristotelian logical system)

influenced.contribution_en: Invention of Eyeglasses (Italian craftsmen were likely inspired by the dissemination of Bacon's writings)
Descartes (his work on optics followed the geometric optical tradition established by Bacon)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Roger Bacon was a scientific prophet in the medieval darkness, foreseeing a future of telescopes, cars, and planes.

quiz.question_en: In 'Opus Majus', what did Roger Bacon suggest lenses could be used for, based on optical principles?
quiz.explanation_en: Bacon correctly deduced that convex lenses magnify objects, stating 'this instrument is useful to old men and those with weak eyes'. This directly foreshadowed the invention of spectacles.
